value: Sulaymaniyah remains one of the most dangerous cities on Earth and is emphatically
a tourist destination. Those who are travelling here on business are strongly advised to consult their own government first and have an armed guard with them. Otherwise do not even

There is an international  "Sulaimaniya Airport" near Bakrajo, with direct flights from Dusseldorf-Germany, Dubai-UAE, Amman-Jordan, and Istanbul-Turkey. There are many services per day and people from all over the world come to enjoy the most beautiful nature in Iraq

The international airport was opened in 2006 and is in the western part of the city. The majority of flights are operated by Kurdish Airlines. Fly Air connects Sulaimaniya with Turkey, Hamburg International with Munich and Frankfurt, and several other airlines also with Stockholm and Kopenhagen. 

Fly Hellas flies to As Sulaymaniyah from Athens.

Atlas Jet From Istanbul also flies to AS Sulaymaniyah every Saturday night.

Sulaimaniya has a great view from outside, above the mountains around it (Goizha, Azmar, Piramagrwn and Baranan). The city is in the phase of transition from a usual city to a tourism city in every sense of the word.

value: : It is the second biggest museum after the national museum in Baghdad. It is home to many Kurdish and ancient Persian artifacts dating back to 1792â€“1750 BC.

(Kurdish:"Red Intelligence Museum")is located in a former Ba'ath intelligence headquarters and prison, it draws particular attention to the Ba'ath regime's brutal treatment of local Kurds. Visitors are guided through the prisons and interrogation rooms. The museum features many Soviet-era armored fighting vehicles.
: Open year-round, it displays the works of the artists of the city. It is run by "Rostam Aghala",a well-known modern Kurdish artist.
: Another place for artistic activities. It started the night cinema project where people can go to watch Kurdish and foreign films.

There is a bowling centre, Azadi park and other places to visit.

value: (Go to the East end of Salm Street, where the gate to the bazaar area is, and then 300 meters North, uphill.  Or go to Southeast corner of Azadi park.  In either case, look for a large silver dome on top of its building.) has appointed itself as the source for Western products. They don't have much, but they are more likely to have something else than other stores.

Coffee is not big in Suli, and tea is generally a better bet.  As with anything here, there are many shops with basically the same selection.  The local taste is for instant coffee, and the coffee section of a grocery store will be dominated by MacCoffee and Nescafe.  Coffee beans generally come only as little bricks of Turkish coffee, 200 grams roasted dark and ground fine.  If you don't want 1/4 cardamom, check the package to make sure it says 100% coffee.

value: directions=In the bazaar area, Walk through the gate opposite the Palace Hotel, and straight up the street to the first circle with the booksellers, go around them, and take the shallow right and look for Pasha's on the left

content=One of the only places in town with proper coffee. They have a sign in Latin characters, and there is usually a crowd of coffee drinkers out front. You can get good espresso from the machine and they have bulk coffee (28 000 for a kilo of Columbian beans) and coffee makers in styles unavailable elsewhere.
content=For now, this is the best hotel in town, although it is by no means up to international standards. Nevertheless, it's a decent enough experience
